thread.title: NFL Confidential: Pair of young QBs are losing promise
thread.title_full: NFL Confidential: Pair of young QBs are losing promise

author: Vito Stellino
title: NFL Confidential: Pair of young QBs are losing promise
text:
NFL Confidential: Pair of young QBs are losing promise 
By Vito Stellino Sat, Oct 10, 2015 @ 6:29 pm | updated Sun, Oct 11, 2015 @ 9:18 am Photos AP Miami Dolphins' Ryan Tannehill passes the ball during the NFL football game between the New York Jets and the Miami Dolphins and at Wembley stadium in London, Sunday, Oct. 4, 2015. 
Not so long ago, Colin Kaepernick and Ryan Tannehill were considered quarterbacks with bright futures who both got big contracts because they were the face of their respective franchises. 
Now the question is whether one or both will become another Ryan Fitzpatrick , who got a big contract in Buffalo but then struggled and was released after the 2012 season. 
Fitzpatrick is now on his third team in the last three years although he’s starting with the Jets, mainly because Geno Smith suffered a broken jaw when punched by a teammate. 
Kaepernick and Tannehill are both struggling this year and the 49ers and Dolphins are both 1-3. The Dolphins fired coach Joe Philbin last week. 
Kaepernick, a second-round pick in 2011, took the 49ers to a Super Bowl and to the NFC title game in 2013. But the 49ers slipped to 8-8 last year and coach Jim Harbaugh , who was feuding with management, was fired. 
This year, the wheels have come off for Kaepernick, who doesn’t have the same players around him and looks lost. He threw four interceptions against Arizona two weeks ago and that carried over in a 17-3 loss to Green Bay last week. Four times Kaepernick threw deep sideline passes out of bounds to avoid interceptions. He was picked off just once. 
“That’s something where you’re going to have that in the back of your mind,’’ Kaepernick said of the interceptions. “You protect the football.’’ 
In the last two games, the 49ers were outscored 64-10 and Kaepernick’s passer rating was 25.6. His overall passer rating of 67.7 is third-worst in the league. He still has his job, mainly because his backup is Blaine Gabbert . 
Tannehill never enjoyed the initial success Kaepernick had because the Dolphins weren’t as talented. Still, after a pair of 8-8 seasons, the Dolphins gave Tannehill a contract worth more than $19 million a year. 
Through four games, Tannehill’s passer rating is 77.1, fifth-worst in the league, a spot behind Fitzpatrick and two above Kaepernick. 
Even worse was his last practice in London before the Dolphins were beaten by the Jets, 27-14. 
During a walkthrough, the defensive players showed a lack of respect for Tannehill by intercepting his passes. The defensive players are supposed to shadow the receivers as they run through the offensive game plan in a walkthrough. They aren’t supposed to disrupt it. 
Tannehill reacted by saying they should get a practice squad trophy, though he denied a report that he referred to their small paychecks. The incident was quickly leaked to the news media and became a symbol of the team’s dysfunction. 
Tannehill apologized for his reaction after the team returned to Miami and Philbin was fired. 
Interim coach Dan Campbell , who tried to change the culture by holding an Oklahoma drill last week, will stick with Tannehill for now because the backup is journeyman Matt Moore . A new coach next year may decide to rebuild with a new quarterback unless Tannehill starts playing better. 

Owner does talking 
The Detroit Lions came up with a unique way of publicly protesting the non-call at the end of their Monday night loss to Seattle when linebacker K.J. Wright illegally batted a ball out of the end zone. 
The NFL frowns on publicly criticizing officials, so coach Jim Caldwell said owner Martha Firestone Ford gave league officials an earful at the league meetings in New York last week. 
“Don’t think Mrs. Ford is not upset,’’ Caldwell said. “Don’t think she is just sitting around not saying anything, OK? Don’t think she doesn’t give them a piece of her mind.’’ 
She is the widow of long-time Lions owner William Clay Ford , a grandson of Henry Ford . She’s also the granddaughter of Harvey Firestone , the Firestone tire founder. 
She has kept a low profile since her husband died a year ago and spoke to the media in a formal setting for the first time at the start of minicamp. 
By saying the owner was upset, Caldwell avoided risking a fine himself. 
Still, all that doesn’t change the fact that the NFL rulebook is too complicated and the officials miss too many calls. 
Wright said he didn’t know it was illegal to bat the ball out of the end zone and it is not reviewable because the league considers it a “judgment’’ call. It can be a judgment call if it’s knocked out in a scrum, but Wright was by himself when he batted it out and later admitted he did it on purpose. 

Fans need a win 
The Jaguars’ game in Tampa Sunday is not only important to staying a game behind the Colts in the AFC South, but keeping the fan base engaged. 
A large contingent of Jaguars fans will be making the trip to Tampa, but the casual fans at home may tune them out if they don’t beat the Buccaneers. 
The Jaguars first two games were viewed in 164,000 households and the figure spiked to 173,000 for the New England game after the Jaguars beat Miami. But only 153,000 viewed the loss to Indianapolis after the lopsided loss at New England. 
The Jaguars need more success to keep the fans interested. 

Crowded at the top 
If the Patriots beat the Cowboys on Sunday, the league will have had six 4-0 teams for the first time in league history. 
The other five are the Falcons, Panthers, Bengals, Broncos and Packers. 
Teams that are 4-0 have a big edge in the playoff chase. Since the current playoff format started in 1990, 59 of the 71 (83 percent) 4-0 teams made the playoffs. 
By contrast, only one 0-4 team — the 1992 San Diego Chargers — reached the postseason. The Chargers went 11-1 the rest of the way that year to make the playoffs at 11-5. 
Detroit is the only 0-4 team this year. 

Quotable 
“Right now he’s a one-year wonder. I’m just being honest. It’s just one year.’’ Jets cornerback Antonio Cromartie on Giants receiver Odell Beckham , who has 24 catches and is on pace to top his total of 91 catches as a rookie. The Giants face the Jets on Dec. 6.
